jaynesian probability - pairwise distance

Jan 26, 2019

Consider a pair of aligned nucleotide sequences of length $L$, having $n$ different sites. What is most probable distance $\theta$ between the two sequences assuming they evolve under the Jukes & Cantor (1969) model? Recall that a distance is the expected number of substitutions per site, and is proportional to the product of a rate times a time $\lambda \times t$. We are looking for

The sampling distribution in terms of $n$ is given by the binomial distribution, with $P(s|\theta I)$ the probability of a substitution ($s$) at a site given the distance $\theta$

where $P(s | \theta I)$ is given by the transition probability distribution of the Jukes & Cantor Markov model:

We next need $P(n | LI)$, which can be found by integrating out the dependence on $\theta$, i.e.

So the only thing remaining is a decent prior for $\theta$. What is a reasonable prior for a distance? Jeffreyâ€™s noted that the correct way to express ignorance for a positive continuous parameter is to assign a uniform distribution to its logarithm, resulting in a prior on $\theta$

This is of course improper. We have

Where the binomial coefficients are dropped as they appear both in the numerator and denominator.
